data.title: Class, Nation and Social Change in the Kinks’ England
data.meta_description: Ray Davies was one of a small group of ‘organic intellectuals’ who emerged in the 1960s seeking to explore class, nation and social change through popular music. Like Lennon and Townshend, he saw music as a way of reflecting and shaping the experiences of...
data.text:
see N. Hasted, The Story of the Kinks: You Really Got Me (London, 2011).

See R. Davies, X-Ray: The Unauthorised Autobiography (London, 1996)

D. Davies, Kink: An Autobiography (London, 1996).

M. Shanks, The Stagnant Society (London, 1961)

A. Sampson, The Anatomy of Britain (London, 1962)

A. Koestler, Suicide of a Nation (London, 1963). These books were representative of a literary trend that sought to make sense of the current state of England, its recent past and prospects for the future.

For the CCCS, see S. Hall and T. Jefferson (eds), Resistance Through Rituals: Youth Subcultures in Post-war Britain (London, 1993).

See P. Addison, The Road to 1945: British Politics and the Second World War (London, 1975).

see D. Fraser, ‘The Postwar Consensus: A Debate Not Long Enough’, History, 84, 274 (1999), 301–24.

For a sophisticated analysis of Davies’s work, see T. M. Kitts, Ray Davies: Not Like Everybody Else (London, 2008).

For a survey of the main social and political developments in this period, see A. Marwick, British Society Since 1945 (Harmondsworth, 1982).

R. Hoggart, The Uses of Literacy: Aspects of Working—Class Life with Special Reference to Publications and Entertainments (Harmondsworth, 1957).

see P. Cohen, ‘Subcultural Conflict and Working Class Community’, Working Papers in Cultural Studies, 2 (Birmingham, 1972).

The best sources for the family backgrounds of the Kinks are the autobiographies of Ray Davies and Dave Davies and the various profiles of the Kinks that have been published since the 1980s. See Davies, X-Ray; Davies, Kink, and J. Savage, The Kinks: The Official Biography (London, 1984).

see the following films, Karel Reisz’s Saturday Night and Sunday Morning (1960)

Tony Richardson’s A Taste of Honey (1961)

John Schlesinger’s A Kind of Loving (1962)

Lindsay Anderson’s This Sporting Life (1963).

see J. Hill, Sex, Class and Realism: British Cinema 1956–1963 (London, 1997).

R. Samuel, Island Stories. Unravelling Britain: Theatres of Memory Vol. II, A. Light, S. Alexander and G. Stedman Jones (eds) (London, 1998), p. 160.

G. Orwell, The Lion and the Unicorn: Socialism and the English Genius (Harmondsworth, 1990).

See M. J. Krause, ‘The Greatest Rock Star of the 19th Century: Ray Davies, Romanticism, and the Art of being English’, Popular Music and Society, 29, 1 (2006), 201–12.

M. Cloonan, ‘State of the Nation: Englishness, Pop, and Politics in the Mid-1990s’, Popular Music and Society, 21, 2 (1997), 47–70.

N. Baxter-Moore, ‘This Is Where I Belong: Identity, Social Class, and the Nostalgic Englishness of Ray Davies and the Kinks’, Popular Music and Society, 29, 2 (2006), 145–65.

G. Orwell, The Road to Wigan Pier (London, 1937).

For discussion of Orwell’s politics, see S. Ingle, George Orwell: A Political Life (Manchester, 1993), chapters 5 and 6.

N. Dunn, Up the Junction (London, 1968), pp. 51–2.

P. Willmott, Adolescent Boys of East London (Harmondsworth, 1966), p. 19.

For an autobiographical insight into ‘northern clubland’ in the 1960s, see the memoirs of Manchester comedian Les Dawson. L. Dawson, A Clown Too Many (Glasgow, 1985).

L. Hanley, Estates: An Intimate History (London, 2007), p. 76.

see D. Hinman, The Kinks All Day and All of the Night: Day-by-Day Concerts, Recordings and Broadcasts, 1961–1996 (San Francisco, 2004).

see J. Hinton, ‘Militant Housewives: The British Housewives’ League and the Attlee Government’, History Workshop Journal, 38, 1 (1994), 129–156.

see G. Pearson, Hooligan: A History of Respectable Fears (Basingstoke, 1983).

F. Mort, Capital Affairs: London and the Making of the Permissive Society (New Haven, 2010), p. 340.

See also G. Moorhouse, Britain in the Sixties: The Other England (Harmondsworth, 1964)

K. Coates and R. Silburn, Poverty: The Forgotten Englishmen (Harmondsworth, 1970).

The films of Ken Loach also convincingly depict the continuities in pre-war and post-war working-class consciousness and the ‘structure of feeling’ that remained a feature of everyday life and the culture that emerged from the home, the workplace and the street. For a critical reading of Loach’s films see J. Hill, Ken Loach: The Politics of Film and Television (London, 2011).

For an examination of the planning culture that led to Ronan Point, see D. Sandbrook, White Heat, (London, 2006), chapter 29.

For the Aberfan disaster and its aftermath see I. McLean, ‘On Moles and the Habits of Birds: The Unpolitics of Aberfan’, Twentieth Century British History, 8, 3 (1997), 285–309.

J. Patrick, A Glasgow Gang Observed (London, 1973), pp. 110–11.

M. Morse, The Unattached (Harmondsworth, 1965), p. 116.

For Manchester, see L. Jackson, ‘The Coffee Club Menace: Policing Youth, Leisure and Sexuality in Post-war Manchester’, Cultural and Social History, 5, 3 (2008), 289–308.

N. Dunn, Poor Cow (London, 1967).

For an insightful analysis of class, gender and popular culture in the 1960s, see S. Rowbotham, Promise of a Dream: Remembering the Sixties (Harmondsworth, 2000).

For a recent re-appraisal of the Rolling Stones’ depiction of women, see A. August, ‘Gender and 1960s Youth Culture: The Rolling Stones and the New Woman’, Contemporary British History, 23, 1 (2009), 79–100.

For a perceptive assessment of the characterisation of film in this period, see Geraghty, ‘Women and Sixties British Cinema: The Development of the “Darling” Girl’, in Robert Murphy (ed.), The British Cinema Book (London, 1997), pp. 154–63.

For a recent re-appraisal of their work, see M. Savage, Identities and Social Change in Britain Since 1940: The Politics of Method (Oxford, 2010).

M. Young and P. Willmott, Family and Kinship in East London (Harmondsworth, 1986), p. 61.

Paul Barker, ‘Young Marriage’, in T. Raison (ed.), Youth in New Society (London, 1966), p. 179.

For discussion of these figures, see R. McKibbin, Classes and Cultures: England, 1918–1951 (Oxford, 1998), pp. 127–37.

A. Sillitoe, Saturday Night and Sunday Morning (London, 1958).

S. Barstow, A Kind of Loving (London, 1960).

J. Bourke, Working-Class Cultures in Britain, 1890–1960: Gender, Class and Ethnicity (London, 1996), p. 137.

For discussion, see E. Hedling, Lindsay Anderson: Maverick Film-maker (London, 1998), pp. 43–5.

See G. Orwell, ‘The Art of Donald McGill’, in G. Orwell, Decline of the English Murder (Harmondsworth, 2011).

M. Waite, ‘Sex ‘n’ Drugs ‘n’ Rock ‘n’ Roll (and Communism) in the 1960s’, in G. Andrews, N. Fishman and K. Morgan (eds), Opening the Books: Essays on the Social and Cultural History of the British Communist Party (London, 1995), pp. 218–19.

J. Street, Rebel Rock: The Politics of Popular Music (Oxford, 1986), p. 221.

T. Dan Smith was the autocratic and enigmatic Labour figure in Newcastle politics who was eventually imprisoned for corruption. For background and details of the case, see R. Fitzwalter and D. Taylor, Web of Corruption: The Story of John Poulson and T. Dan Smith (London, 1981).

C. H. Rolph, Women of the Streets: A Sociological Study of the Common Prostitute for the British Social Biology Council (London, 1961), pp. 112–13.

J. Sandford, Prostitutes (London, 1977), p. 112.

M. M. Lupro, ‘Preserving the Old Ways, Protecting the New: Post—War British Urban Planning in The Kinks Are the Village Green Preservation Society’, Popular Music and Society, 29, 2 (2006), p. 190.

P. S. Bagwell, The Railwaymen: The History of the National Union of Railwaymen Vol. 2: The Beeching Era and After (London, 1982), p. 24.

R. Samuel, Theatres of Memory Vol. 1: Past and Present in Contemporary Culture, (London, 1994), p. 271.

P. Willmott and M. Young, Family and Class in a London Suburb (London, 1967), p. 23.

For the creation of ‘Selsdon man’ and its impact, see J. Campbell, Edward Heath. A Biography (London, 1993), pp. 265–7.

see P. Stead, Film and the Working Class: The Feature Film in British and American Society (London, 1989)

A. Aldgate and J. Richards, Best of British: Cinema and Society From 1930 to the Present (London, 1999), chapter 10.

R. Denselow, When the Music’s Over: The Story of Political Pop (London, 1989), p. 95.

See R. Tyler, ‘Victims of Our History? Barbara Castle and In Place of Strife’, Contemporary British History, 20, 3 (2006), 461–76.

P. Mandler, The English National Character: The History of an Idea from Edmund Burke to Tony Blair (New Haven, 2006), p. 189.

For references to Dave Davies and bisexuality, see S. Napier-Bell, Black Vinyl White Powder (London, 2002), p. 72.

For background, see J. Weeks, Coming Out: Homosexual Politics in Britain from the Nineteenth Century to the Present (London, 1983), chapters 14–16.

M. Houlbrook, Queer London: Perils and Pleasures in the Sexual Metropolis, 1918–1957 (Chicago, 2005), p. 223.

For description of this milieu, see J. Reed, The King of Carnaby Street. The Life of John Stephen (London, 2010), p. 85.

J. Nuttall, Bomb Culture (London, 1970), p. 34.

For Raymond, see P. Willetts, Members Only: The Life and Times of Paul Raymond (London, 2010).

F. Mort, ‘Striptease: The Erotic Female Body and Live Sexual Entertainment in Mid-Twentieth-Century London’, Social History, 23, 1 (2007), 53.

For a detailed exploration of English pornography in this period, see G. Freeman, The Undergrowth of Literature (London, 1969).

John Smith became leader of the Labour Party in 1992. Interview with Davies, Independent, 27 August 1994.
